title: The Islamic World in the Modern Age (1800â€“Present)

text: From the 1800s onwards, the Islamic world faced a period different from previous centuries. This period was shaped by developments such as industrialization, the formation of modern state structures, globalization, educational reforms, and rapid change of societies. The modern age is a multifaceted transformation process in the Islamic world where both difficulties and new opportunities emerged.

content.section: 1. Industrial Revolution and the New World Order
text: The Industrial Revolution, which started in Europe in the 18th and 19th centuries, radically changed world balances. This change directly affected the Islamic geography.

made it mandatory for the Islamic world to re-evaluate its international relations in this period. Modern institutions, new education methods, and administrative arrangements were born from this need in many regions.
Throughout the 19th and 20th centuries, new political structures were established in the Islamic geography. Independent and modern nation-states began to replace old empires like the Ottoman Empire.
These changes were important steps determining the future of societies.

The modern age stood out with the spread of education and the establishment of modern schools in the Islamic world. While traditional educational institutions continued their existence, new curricula were created in fields such as science, mathematics, history, and social sciences.

In the modern age, the Islamic world is a very wide and dynamic geography that has:

This period is a modern reflection of the diversity maintained by Islamic civilization throughout history. The balance between change and tradition has become one of the basic characteristics of today's Islamic societies.
